results.title: Kabul’s Sudden Fall to Taliban Ends U.S. Era in Afghanistan
results.abstract: A takeover of the entire country was all but absolute as the Afghan government collapsed and the U.S. rushed through a frenzied evacuation.
results.byline: By David Zucchino, Jim Huylebroek and Kiana Hayeri

multimedia.caption: Taliban fighters in Kabul, the capital, on Sunday on a Humvee seized from Afghan forces. The speed of the Taliban’s sweep through the country startled American officials.
multimedia.copyright: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

results.title: A Week Into Taliban Rule, One City’s Glimpse of What the Future May Hold
results.abstract: In Kunduz, the new insurgent leaders said they had no quarrel with the people. But residents say they soon began instilling fear.
results.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim

multimedia.caption: Taliban fighters in Kunduz, Afghanistan, early last week. The city was the first in a series to rapidly fall to the insurgents.

results.title: In an Overrun Kabul, Many Have No Place to Run
results.abstract: Afghanistan’s capital fell to the Taliban far faster than many had imagined it would, leaving most Afghans with no way out.
results.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Christina Goldbaum, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Ruhullah Khapalwak

results.title: In Zambia Election, Opposition Leader Storms to Decisive Win Over President
results.abstract: Voters picked Hakainde Hichilema, a businessman who had lost five previous bids for the job, to take over from Edgar Lungu, who has led the southern African nation since 2015.

multimedia.caption: Hakainde Hichilema speaking at his home in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, on Wednesday. His victory was seen as a resounding rebuke of his rival’s shepherding of an economy that was in tatters.
Hakainde Hichilema speaking at his home in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, on Wednesday. His victory was seen as a resounding rebuke of his rival’s shepherding of an economy that was in tatters.

results.title: Trudeau Calls Early Election in Canada
results.abstract: The prime minister hopes his handling of the pandemic will help his Liberal Party win a majority in the House of Commons. Opponents say voting amid a Covid surge is dangerous.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau greets supporters at a campaign stop in Ottawa on Sunday.

results.title: ‘Our Hands and Feet Are Tied’: Hong Kong’s Opposition Quits in Droves
results.abstract: The landslide victory of pro-democracy politicians in local elections in 2019 was a stunning rebuke of Beijing. Now, fear of retaliation has driven them to quit.
results.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May

multimedia.caption: A pro-democracy district councilor handing out copies of Apple Daily in Hong Kong in August 2020, after the newspaper’s founder, Jimmy Lai, was arrested under the national security law.

results.title: Japan’s Economy Returns to Growth, but Virus Threat Looms
results.abstract: Even as other major economies have roared back to life, Japan’s has been stuck in a cycle of growth and contraction.

results.title: Afghans storm Kabul’s airport in a desperate bid to escape.
results.abstract: The U.S. military took charge of security over part of the airport’s civilian side as thousands rushed the tarmac. Some hung from jets even as they taxied down the runway.
results.byline: By Austin Ramzy, Carlotta Gall and Marc Santora

results.title: Australia’s worsening outbreak raises concerns about Aboriginal communities.
results.abstract: With the Delta variant spreading, only 15 percent of Indigenous people over the age of 16 have been fully inoculated, well behind the national level, according to officials.

results.title: Patagonia, Adorned in Autumn
results.abstract: Southern Chile’s snow-capped mountains, vast plains and windswept lakes are often depicted in summertime. See the landscape dressed in autumnal hues.

results.title: ‘I’m the Only Surgeon’: After Haiti Quake, Thousands Seek Scarce Care
results.abstract: A day after a magnitude-7.2 earthquake killed an estimated 1,300 people in western Haiti, the country, already suffering from a dire lack of doctors, struggled to help the many wounded.
